title: Former Pacific leader slams Morrison over climate change
text:
Canberra | A former Pacific Island leader has accused Scott Morrison of prioritising "making money" over "saving lives" through his ongoing support for the coal industry.

Tuvalu's former prime minister Enele Sopoaga warned that $500 million promised by the Morrison government under the "Pacific step-up" to spend on climate change mitigation projects in the region was grossly inadequate compared with the damage being wrought by global warming.

Tuvalu's former prime minister Enele Sopoaga has criticised Scott Morrison's approach to climate change at the Pacific Islands Forum AAP

At the same time, however, Mr Sopoaga, who lost his re-election bid last month, also poured scorn on China's attempts to build influence in the Pacific, deriding their efforts as "money diplomacy".

Mr Sopoaga was the keynote speaker at the national conference of the Australian Council for International Development, the peak body for foreign aid groups, held in Sydney on Wednesday.

As host of the Pacific Islands Forum in August, Mr Sopoaga was angered by Australia's refusal to sign up to a leaders' communique urging a ban on new coal mines and on new coal-fired power stations.
description: Tuvalu's former prime minister has used a visit to Australia to revive Pacific leaders' frustration over climate change inaction.
